nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based teacher evaluation causes lasting improvements in teacher effectiveness (skill or effort) as measured by student math achievement

Setting and intervention: Cincinnati Public Schools Teacher Evaluation System (TES) is a year-long, rubric-based classroom observation program where each teacher is observed multiple times by trained peer evaluators and an administrator and receives written feedback and final domain scores

Analysis sample and data: mid-career fourth–eighth grade math teachers hired 1993–1999, observed 2003–2010, merged TES observation and score data to student-level standardized math test scores and covariates

Identification strategy: teacher fixed effects model comparing within-teacher performance before, during, and after evaluation, controlling for grade-by-year fixed effects, student prior achievement and covariates, and a quadratic in teacher experience (capped)

Primary result: students taught in years after a teacher's TES evaluation score about 0.112 standard deviations higher in math than students taught by the same teacher before evaluation (statistically significant)

During-evaluation result: students taught during the teacher's TES year have modestly higher math scores (about 0.052 s.d.) but this estimate is less precisely estimated and often not statistically significant

Mechanism interpretation and limitation: gains are consistent with teachers receiving new individualized performance information leading to skill development or persistent effort change, but the exact behavioral changes cannot be identified from the data

TES program detail relevant to mechanism: multiple peer observations, written feedback after each observation, final summative scores across domains, rubrics tied to instructional practices (micro-level feedback less subject to leniency than final scores)

TES implementation features: teachers typically evaluated every five years; first evaluations for phased-in veteran teachers were scheduled by hire year, creating quasi-experimental variation in evaluation timing

Outcome measurement: student end-of-year math test scores standardized by grade and year; student controls include prior-year score, demographics, special education, gifted status, English proficiency, retention

Threats and checks: concerns include nonrandom student assignment, preexisting teacher trends, voluntary early participation, and attrition; authors conduct event-study, covariate balance tests, scheduled-year instrumentation, and attrition analyses

Robustness and identification evidence: event study shows no clear pre-evaluation upward trend; estimates robust to omitting experience controls, using scheduled evaluation as instrument (2SLS), and to restricting sample to teachers observed both before and after evaluation

Heterogeneity: postevaluation gains are larger for teachers with low pre-TES test-score value-added, for teachers with low TES scores, for teachers whose TES scores grew most during the TES year, and larger for math-specialist teachers than self-contained teachers

Attrition analysis: small attrition after TES year consistent with district norms; results robust when weighting for predicted persistence and when restricting to non-attriters; attrition would need large negatively affected attriters to explain away main result

Cost and policy consideration: TES program direct budget roughly $1.8–2.1 million per year (about $7,500 per teacher evaluated), plus opportunity cost of using high-performing teachers as peer evaluators which may reduce classroom achievement; net benefits depend on evaluator selection and number of teachers who improve

Conclusion: well-structured, observation-based subjective evaluation can serve beyond sorting and selective dismissal to function as effective, potentially lasting professional development for teachers and may generalize to other sectors where individualized performance information is scarce
